Comment: Answer: US government is composed of three main branches. The Legislative branch, the House and Senate create laws, and the Executive branch, the President enacts those laws by signing (or not- by using the veto power the president holds). The Judicial branch enforces those laws. By using case law to interpret how and when those laws are to be enforced.  In 1990 Bush signed the Americans with Disabilities act into law. It said essentially that the government and other entities offering services to the public cannot discriminate against persons with disabilities. Sounds great, right? Except it was, like many laws, kinda vague on just what form that discrimination had to take to be in violation of the law. Mostly in how the law applied when an entity was remodeling, or renovating, or otherwise altering an existing structure or facility.   Enter [Kinney V Yerusalem:](https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/812/547/1761223/) A group of persons with disabilities sued a State transportation department for violating the ADA. When the State repaved a road, they argued, it had the legal responsibility under the ADA to also install compliant curb ramps at every crosswalk on that road. Because crosswalks are a public facility, and by not making them compliant the State was in violation of the law.  The State argued that their concern was only the road, the crosswalks and curb ramps were not required to be upgraded at that time.  The Supreme Court ruled that, no, by paving the road they were altering the existing crosswalks and thus triggering the legal requirement to upgrade them.    So case law determines how and when laws are to be applied for those times the law isn't clear. That's the power SCOTUS has and is why case law is so important in the US legal system. There are many more fascinating cases where the courts ruled in ways that importantly affected just how and when laws are applied.

Comment: The United States, like most former British colonies, has a "common law" judicial system, which means that the Constitution and the Laws passed by congress are interpreted by the courts based on the past rulings of courts called "precedent." The government is expected to apply that ruling going forward, and other courts are expected to interpret following that ruling until Congress changes the law or the Supreme Court changes its decision (which is supposed to happen very rarely but is increasingly common)  gave a good description of what that looks like in practice  Almost all European countries (except Britain and Ireland) have a judicial system based on a "civil code", where judges interpret the law based on written law codes and do not consider the rulings of past courts.  So, in the US (and any common law system), one Supreme Court ruling can dramatically change how a law is applied for decades to come, whereas, in a Civil Code system, one ruling only affects the narrow issue it is being applied to.  [https://www.law.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/CommonLawCivilLawTraditions.pdf](https://www.law.berkeley.edu/wp-content/uploads/2017/11/CommonLawCivilLawTraditions.pdf)  Additionally, SC Justices are appointed for life, and there are relatively few of them (compared to the SC of most countries), and there is no real mechanism for holding them accountable.

Comment: That was the great debate of the 1830s-1850s: [Nullification](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nullification_(U.S._Constitution)#The_nullification_crisis).  Nowdays, nullification is out, but it's still possible to challenge that federal law in the federal courts on constitutional grounds. If found unconstitutional, that federal law can't be enforced and state or local law stands. Unless it's successfully challenged in state court...  Further, to sue to challenge constitutionality, the plaintiff must have standing - face actual harm from the action of the law. In the case of abortion, it's possible to argue that the only party who could possibly have standing is the fetus. That leads to arguments over whether a fetus is a person, another requirement to have standing. The amicus briefs would be flying!
